poem:
Title: Frost-Bitten Promises

In the steel shaped shadows of Sheffield town, 
Where promised warmth came poorly clad.
Two shivering souls, upturned to frown,
Upon a night icy and dread.

Cold calls rang up, in futile fight,
Booking's promise rang hollow, left bare.
The kindest hearth, no spark, no light,
Where was hospitality's fair share?

On a snowy eve they stood, disheartened and slight
Testament of unkept vows in frozen night.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Booking.com’s measly customer service left us out in the cold I booked a flat in Sheffield for myself and my two elderly grandmothers as we were attending a family event. We paid £160. When we arrived, on a cold snowy night, the heating was not working. The extreme cold was a risk to my grandmothers, and I tried, in vain, to remedy the situation with the host and Booking.com. It was too late to find". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
